summary: One-year MS in Human Nutrition Program Webinar
locationaddress: Online Event
categories: Medical Center,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Webcast,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Basic Health Sciences,Clinical Health Sciences,Postdocs,org/cumc_ihn,Admissions,Prospective Students,Healthcare,Graduate Students,College of Physicians and Surgeons,Columbia Nursing,Mailman School of Public Health,Trainees,Education,org/EI,org/cumc
description: <p>The <strong>1-year Columbia MS in Human Nutrition</strong> involves an intense year of study; thesis research with options in basic nutrition science, clinical nutrition, and public health nutrition; and preparation for medical school, as well as a broad range of new and important healthcare careers.</p>\n<p>Join our webinar and alumni panel discussion, where Institute faculty, staff, and alumni will&nbsp;provide an overview of our one-year MS in Human Nutrition program with insights on career paths and program highlights from the alumni.&nbsp;The session will close with a Q&amp;A. Click &#39;Register for the Webinar&#39; above to register. We look forward to speaking with you.</p>

description: <p>The Center for Improving Palliative Care for Vulnerable Adults with Multiple Chronic Conditions invites you to &quot;CIPC Pilot Presentations,&quot; a seminar presented by Dr. Bevin Cohen, Director of the Center for Nursing Research and Innovation for the Mount Sinai Health System and Associate Professor in the Brookdale Department of Geriatric and Palliative Medicine at the Icahn School of Medicine, Dr. Maureen George, Professor of Nursing at Columbia University School of Nursing and Assistant Dean for Scholarship &amp; Research, and Dr.&nbsp;Jiyoun&nbsp;Song,&nbsp;Postdoctoral Fellow in Nursing Informatics at Columbia University.&nbsp;</p>

summary: CTLgrads Office Hours (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>We invite current Columbia graduate student with&nbsp;questions about teaching&nbsp;to drop by office hours anytime today from 2:00&ndash;4:00 pm. We also welcome conversations about CTL fellowships, programs, services, job market preparation, and making progress in the Teaching Development Program (tdp.ctl.columbia.edu).</p>\n<p>No appointment is necessary; you can join us in-person in 212 Butler Library, or via Zoom at https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/my/ctlgrads.</p>\n<p>If&nbsp;you can&#39;t make office hours but want support, you can request an individual consultation at http://bit.ly/ctl-gradconsult or email us at CTLgrads@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: The Wellness Circle
locationaddress: The Forum at Columbia University, 601 W. 125th St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Forum, in partnership with the <a href="https://harlemwellness.org/" target="_blank">Harlem Wellness Center</a>, will host weekly chair stretches and meditation sessions on Wednesdays starting January 18th in the West Atrium.</p>\n<p><strong>Free and open to all. Please register <a href="https://airtable.com/shrfmoj1CH8W4Ciy9" target="_blank">here.</a></strong></p>

summary: Monthly overview of IRI's Global Seasonal Climate Forecasts and ENSO status and forecast.
locationaddress: Online
description: The International Research Institute for Climate and Society (IRI) presents its climate forecast briefing. The IRI's seasonal, sub-seasonal and ENSO (El Niño Southern Oscillation) forecasts are discussed in this monthly briefing by IRI climate scientists Azhar Ehsan and Bohar Singh.\nFor more information, please see: https://iri.columbia.edu/our-expertise/climate/

summary: Mobke Presents : Jazz Transatlantic
locationaddress: Buell Hall, 515 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p><strong>RSVP&nbsp;<a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/489774006237">HERE</a></strong></p>\n<p><strong>Th&eacute;o Girard&nbsp;</strong>has been active on the French jazz scene for 20 years. As the 2022 laureate of the &quot;Creative Grant&quot; of the FACE Foundation &quot;Jazz and New Music&#39;&#39; program, Th&eacute;o Girard is coming to New York and the Columbia Maison Fran&ccedil;aise with the Mobke Quartet as a first stop in his quest to explore the roots of jazz in the U.S. and the energy of American cities like New York that have inspired it. Future trips will take him to Chicago, New Orleans, and Los Angeles.</p>\n<p><strong>Mobke&nbsp;</strong>is a French-American quartet with two men and two women musicians from different generations who bring complementary experiences and styles to their music. They will be playing original and improvised jazz music.</p>

summary: Yoga Class
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Take a break to relax and refresh with yoga in Earl Hall. Free yoga classes (open level) will be offered in the Auditorium in Earl Hall every&nbsp;Thursday evening&nbsp;during the fall 2022 semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>No pre-registration required;&nbsp;open to all Columbia University students. Please bring your own mat and arrive 5-10 minutes early to sign in and set up.&nbsp;There is a 5 minute late policy, doors close at 7:05pm, or when the room has reached max capacity. 75 students maximum.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Please note that after spring break, the yoga classes will be offered from 5-6pm for the rest of the semester.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Introduction to the Bloomberg Terminal
locationaddress: Online Event
description: <p>Introduction to the navigation and functionally of the Bloomberg Terminal with an emphasis on popular shortcuts. Some of the topics covered are company and industry research, company&rsquo;s financial information like balance sheet, company filings etc. Bloomberg Law, Bloomberg University and Bloomberg Market Concept certificate program.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>

summary: CTLgrads Office Hours (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>We invite current Columbia graduate student with&nbsp;questions about teaching&nbsp;to drop by office hours anytime today from 2:00&ndash;4:00 pm. We also welcome conversations about CTL fellowships, programs, services, job market preparation, and making progress in the Teaching Development Program (tdp.ctl.columbia.edu).</p>\n<p>No appointment is necessary; you can join us in-person in 212 Butler Library, or via Zoom at https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/my/ctlgrads.</p>\n<p>If&nbsp;you can&#39;t make office hours but want support, you can request an individual consultation at http://bit.ly/ctl-gradconsult or email us at CTLgrads@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: Lenfest Kids: 'My Neighbor Totoro'
locationaddress: Lenfest Center for the Arts, 615 W. 129 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>FREE Family Friendly Screening at Lenfest Center for the Arts!</p>\n<p>From the legendary Studio Ghibli, creators of <em>Spirited Away</em> and <em>Ponyo</em>, and Academy Award-winning director Hayao Miyazaki, comes a classic tale of magic and adventure for the whole family. In <em>My neighbor Totoro</em>, when sisters Satsuki and Mei move to a new home, they find country life is not as simple as it seems. Their house and nearby woods are full of strange and delightful creatures, including a gigantic but gentle forest spirit called Totoro. Totoro and his friends introduce the girls to a series of adventures in this animated masterpiece.</p>\n<p><a href="https://www.lenfest.arts.columbia.edu/spring-2023-events/lenfest-kids-my-neighbor-totoro" target="_blank"><strong>Free Tickets</strong></a></p>

summary: Pop-Up Concerts: Argus Quartet
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Miller&rsquo;s&nbsp;<em>Pop-Up Concerts</em>&nbsp;resume with the Argus Quartet&mdash;a &ldquo;vivacious foursome that plays canonical standards with authority and verve and approaches modern music with care and assurance&rdquo;&nbsp;<em>(The New Yorker).&nbsp;</em>The group performs an ambitious program of recent works, including two world premieres by members of the ensemble, violinist Giancarlo Latta and cellist Mariel Roberts.</p>\n<p><em>Sit onstage and enjoy a free drink during these hour-long weeknight Pop-Ups concerts, and mingle with the musicians and fellow concertgoers after the show. Onstage seating is first-come, first-served.</em></p>\n<p>Free admission &bull; Doors open at 5:30pm, music at 6:00pm</p>

summary: Human Nutrition Special Seminar: Extreme Metabolism
locationaddress: Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center, 1130 St. Nicholas Ave., New York, NY 10032

summary: Exhibit Opening Reception. Ukraine in Ruins 1941-42, 2022
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Please join us for an opening reception for our exhibit Ukraine in Ruins, 1941-42, 2022.&nbsp;The exhibit consists of 18 black and white acrylic-and-pen paintings, 9&rdquo;x12&rdquo;, on canvas sheets. Seven depict central Kyiv in ruins in 1941-1942, as a result of explosions set off by the retreating Soviets; the paintings were completed in mid-2021. Eleven depict Ukraine in ruins in 2022, as a result of Russia&rsquo;s genocidal war; these were completed during the war, in 2022.</p>

summary: Multi-Faith Fellowship
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Multi-Faith Fellowship provides the rare opportunity for genuine learning and community across faith traditions. Honesty, openness, and humility are core values that make the Multi-Faith Fellowship a unique experience in education and dialogue. Students from all schools and all traditions are welcome to join. Join us for&nbsp;dinner, discussion, and multi-faith dialogue every Wednesday night throughout the semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><a href="https://religiouslife.columbia.edu/content/multi-faith-fellowship" target="_blank">Learn more and apply to be a fellow here</a>.</p>

summary: Introduction to the Bloomberg Terminal
locationaddress: Uris Hall, 3022 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Introduction to the navigation and functionally of the Bloomberg Terminal with an emphasis on popular shortcuts. Some of the topics covered are company and industry research, company&rsquo;s financial information like balance sheet, company filings etc. Bloomberg Law, Bloomberg University and Bloomberg Market Concept certificate program.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>

description: <p>The next installment of the Bioethics in Film: From Screen to Seminar Series is brought to you by Columbia University&#39;s Division of Ethics, the Master&#39;s Program in Bioethics, and the Department of Neurology. In this event we will be screening the award-winning documentary <a href="https://columbiacuimc.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_Jkc9KHbFR32QPUdIfJ5_tw" target="_blank">Seizing Hope (2022)</a>, followed by an expert panel discussion and Q&amp;A.</p>\n<h2><strong><a href="https://columbiacuimc.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_Jkc9KHbFR32QPUdIfJ5_tw" target="_blank">Register here</a></strong></h2>

summary: Yoga Class
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Take a break to relax and refresh with yoga in Earl Hall. Free yoga classes (open level) will be offered in the Auditorium in Earl Hall every&nbsp;Thursday evening&nbsp;during the fall 2022 semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>No pre-registration required;&nbsp;open to all Columbia University students. Please bring your own mat and arrive 5-10 minutes early to sign in and set up.&nbsp;There is a 5 minute late policy, doors close at 7:05pm, or when the room has reached max capacity. 75 students maximum.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Please note that after spring break, the yoga classes will be offered from 5-6pm for the rest of the semester.&nbsp;</p>

summary: CTLgrads Office Hours (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>We invite current Columbia graduate student with&nbsp;questions about teaching&nbsp;to drop by office hours anytime today from 2:00&ndash;4:00 pm. We also welcome conversations about CTL fellowships, programs, services, job market preparation, and making progress in the Teaching Development Program (tdp.ctl.columbia.edu).</p>\n<p>No appointment is necessary; you can join us in-person in 212 Butler Library, or via Zoom at https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/my/ctlgrads.</p>\n<p>If&nbsp;you can&#39;t make office hours but want support, you can request an individual consultation at http://bit.ly/ctl-gradconsult or email us at CTLgrads@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: Vladimir Gandelsman: "A Man Only Needs a Room", Poetry Reading
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <h2>Important Note</h2>\n<p><strong>Registration required. Please note that all attendees must follow Columbia&rsquo;s&nbsp;<a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">COVID-19 Policies and Guidelines</a>. Columbia University is committed to protecting the health and safety of its community.&nbsp; To that end,&nbsp;<strong>all visiting alumni and guests</strong>&nbsp;must meet the University requirement of full vaccination status in order to attend in-person events.&nbsp; Vaccination cards may be checked upon entry to all venues.&nbsp;</strong></p>\n<p>Please join the Harriman Institute to celebrate the publication of Vladimir Gandelsman&#39;s&nbsp;<em>A Man Only Needs a Room: Poetry</em>&nbsp;(New Meridian Press, 2022), the first comprehensive introduction to the poet&#39;s verse in English translation. Gandelsman in this reading will be joined by translators Anna Halberstadt, Olga Livshin and Andrew Janco.</p>

summary: Teaching as Research Seminar (for Grad Students)
locationaddress: Online Event
description: <p>The online&nbsp;Teaching as Research Seminar (TaRS) trains&nbsp;participants&nbsp;to assess the impact of teaching interventions in the classroom. Over the course of these four asynchronous&nbsp;modules, participants gain proficiency in&nbsp;the Teaching as Research (TaR) method by defining an original research question,&nbsp;exploring data collection and assessment tools, and&nbsp;drawing on the support of peers and the instructor to draft a complete TaR proposal.&nbsp;The seminar culminates in the presentation of these proposals to the seminar cohort.</p>\n<p>TaRS will run online from January 30&nbsp;to March 10. While the seminar is running, modules will be activated weekly, and participants can work through them on their own schedule. The online kickoff meeting on Monday, January 30&nbsp;at 4:10pm ET will give an opportunity for participants to meet the facilitator&nbsp;and each other as they start the seminar.</p>\n<p>Applications to participate in&nbsp;TaRS will be open from January 2 to January 20. To apply, and for more information about the seminar, please see the <a href="https://ctl.columbia.edu/graduate-instructors/programs-for-graduate-students/seminars-institutes-for-graduate-students/teaching-as-research-seminar/" target="_blank">TaRS&nbsp;page on the CTL website</a>.</p>

summary: Music Monday at The Forum: Louis Armstrong Jazz Performance Program
locationaddress: The Forum at Columbia University, 601 W. 125th St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p><em>Music Monday</em>&nbsp;is a free and open-to-the public monthly concert series hosted by The Forum. Concerts take place in The Forum&#39;s ground-floor Atrium on Monday evenings, once a month. RSVP is encouraged. Please visit The Forum&#39;s website for the full <a href="https://theforum.columbia.edu/events" target="_blank">calendar of events</a>.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The January event will feature players from the vibrant and forward-looking&nbsp;<a href="https://mpp.music.columbia.edu/louis-armstrong-jazz-performance-program" target="_blank">Louis Armstrong Jazz Performance Program</a>. This on-campus program brings together the many talented and creative jazz players at Columbia University, providing lessons and ensemble practice that&nbsp;incorporate a wide array of stylistic and rhythmic designs. Columbia&#39;s strength is its interdisciplinary approach to jazz studies, and the LAJPP is a central part of a larger mission which sees jazz as a music without borders and a mode for integrating scholarly inquiry with innovative teaching and community dialogue.</p>

summary: Something about the Weather
locationaddress: Lenfest Center for the Arts, 615 W. 129 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p><strong>World premiere.</strong>&nbsp;In this concert, New York-based composer, producer, and performer&nbsp;<strong>Hahn Rowe</strong>&nbsp;will use digital processing alongside traditional instruments and crude, everyday objects to build a fluid, shapeshifting soundscape. Commissioned by Columbia University School of the Arts.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><a href="https://www.lenfest.arts.columbia.edu/spring-2023-events/something-about-weather" target="_blank"><strong>Learn more online</strong></a></p>

summary: Guided Historical Tour
locationaddress: Low Library, 535 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Tour,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Guided Historical Tour,Visitors Center,org/visitorscenter,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees
description: <p>Join this tour to learn more about the history, architecture, and sculpture of Columbia and the Morningside Heights campus. Whether you&#39;re an amateur New York City historian or visiting campus for the first time, you will leave the tour knowing more about our storied past.</p>\n<p>Tours will depart from the Visitors Center, located in Room 213 in Low Library.&nbsp;Please arrive at least 15 minutes prior to the tour time. Tours take place rain or shine. We encourage guests to dress appropriately based upon the weather conditions of their visit day.</p>\n<p>All Visitors Center visitors are required to bring proof of a primary vaccination series to their campus tour. A list of acceptable documentation can be found <a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/content/faqs-regarding-covid-19-vaccination#!#%2Fcu_accordion_item-4780" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>

summary: Virtual Naloxone Training - Open to all Columbia affiliates
locationaddress: Online
description: <p>Columbia Health is a Registered Opioid Overdose Prevention Program, recognized by New York City and State Departments of Health. This designation came as part of a collaboration with researchers from the Mailman School of Public Health and the School of General Studies. As part of this work, Columbia Health is offering virtual Naloxone training via Zoom to members of the Columbia University community. Naloxone kits&nbsp;can be picked up from Columbia Health or mailed to participants upon completion of training.&nbsp;If you would like to learn more about the training, please visit&nbsp;<a href="https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training">https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training</a>.</p>\n<p>Registration required.</p>\n<p><strong>Register for the </strong><strong>February</strong><strong> 1, </strong><strong>12:30 PM </strong><strong>- </strong><strong>1:30 PM</strong><strong> <strong>ET&nbsp;session:</strong></strong> <a href="https://nam02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3D9DJck&amp;data=05%7C01%7Chealthcomm%40cumc.columbia.edu%7Cdd8cc8229d8741a92a0408dafe249cc0%7Cb0002a9b0017404d97dc3d3bab09be81%7C0%7C0%7C638101730462242405%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&amp;sdata=q0xRdUUGqCtpLQjoSgyAwEzDKx0YDr6J3zFEkrXew8A%3D&amp;reserved=0">https://bit.ly/3D9DJck</a></p>

summary: Multi-Faith Fellowship
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Multi-Faith Fellowship provides the rare opportunity for genuine learning and community across faith traditions. Honesty, openness, and humility are core values that make the Multi-Faith Fellowship a unique experience in education and dialogue. Students from all schools and all traditions are welcome to join. Join us for&nbsp;dinner, discussion, and multi-faith dialogue every Wednesday night throughout the semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><a href="https://religiouslife.columbia.edu/content/multi-faith-fellowship" target="_blank">Learn more and apply to be a fellow here</a>.</p>

summary: Book Presentation - Cuban Privilege - Susan Eckstein
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Latin America,Cuba,org/ilas,Postdocs,Government and Public Policy,Prospective Students,Discussion,Graduate Students,Trainees,Political Science
description: <p>Join Susan Eckstein for a presentation of her book&nbsp;<em>Cuban Privilege: The Making of Immigrant Inequality in America.</em></p>\n<p>SUSAN ECKSTEIN is a professor at the Pardee School of Global Studies and in the Sociology Department at Boston University. She has written numerous books and articles on Mexican urban poor, political-economic developments in Cuba, Cuban immigrants, immigration policy, and impacts of Latin American revolutions, and has edited books on Latin American social movements and social rights, and on immigrant impacts in their homelands. Most recently she published <em>Cuban Privilege: The Making of Immigrant Inequality in America.</em> Previously she published <em>How Immigrants Impact Their Homelands</em> (co-editor), <em>The Immigrant Divide: How Cuban Americans Changed the U.S.&nbsp;and Their Homeland, What Justice? Whose Justice? Fighting for Fairness in Latin America</em> (co-editor), <em>Struggles for Social Rights in Latin America </em>(co-editor), <em>Back from the Future: Cuba under Castro, Power and Popular Protest: Latin American Social Movements </em>(editor), <em>The Poverty of Revolution: The State and Urban Poor in Mexico</em> and <em>The Impact of Revolution: A Comparative Analysis of Mexico and Bolivia.</em> She is the recipient of fellowships from the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, the American Council on Learned Societies, the Ford Foundation, John D. and Catherine MacArthur Foundation, Rockefeller Foundation, Tinker Foundation, and Christopher Reynolds Foundation. She has received a number of awards for her publications.</p>

summary: Yoga Class
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Take a break to relax and refresh with yoga in Earl Hall. Free yoga classes (open level) will be offered in the Auditorium in Earl Hall every&nbsp;Thursday evening&nbsp;during the fall 2022 semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>No pre-registration required;&nbsp;open to all Columbia University students. Please bring your own mat and arrive 5-10 minutes early to sign in and set up.&nbsp;There is a 5 minute late policy, doors close at 7:05pm, or when the room has reached max capacity. 75 students maximum.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Please note that after spring break, the yoga classes will be offered from 5-6pm for the rest of the semester.&nbsp;</p>

summary: POSTPONED - Composer Portraits: Suzanne Farrin
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Winner of the Rome Prize and a Guggenheim Fellow, Suzanne Farrin explores the interior worlds of instruments and the visceral potentialities of sound in her music. This Portrait highlights another facet of her artistic practice, as an accomplished performer of the early electronic music instrument ondes Martenot. International Contemporary Ensemble delves into a program of her atmospheric work, including the world premiere of&nbsp;<em>Their Hearts are Columns</em>&nbsp;and selections from&nbsp;<em>Dolce la morte,</em>&nbsp;an opera based on the love poetry of Michelangelo.</p>

summary: CTLgrads Office Hours (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>We invite current Columbia graduate student with&nbsp;questions about teaching&nbsp;to drop by office hours anytime today from 2:00&ndash;4:00 pm. We also welcome conversations about CTL fellowships, programs, services, job market preparation, and making progress in the Teaching Development Program (tdp.ctl.columbia.edu).</p>\n<p>No appointment is necessary; you can join us in-person in 212 Butler Library, or via Zoom at https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/my/ctlgrads.</p>\n<p>If&nbsp;you can&#39;t make office hours but want support, you can request an individual consultation at http://bit.ly/ctl-gradconsult or email us at CTLgrads@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: What Makes Good Short Story Good? A Conversation with Maxim Osipov
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
description:
Location Note
1219 International Affairs Building
420 W 118th Street, 12th floor
This is a hybrid (in-person/virtual) event. Registration required for attendance. Please note that all attendees must follow Columbia’s COVID-19 Policies and Guidelines. Columbia University is committed to protecting the health and safety of its community. To that end, all visiting alumni and guests must meet the University requirement of full vaccination status in order to attend in-person events. Vaccination cards may be checked upon entry to all venues. All other attendees may participate virtually on Zoom or YouTube.
Please join the Harriman Institute for a conversation with Maxim Osipov, moderated by Mark Lipovetsky.

summary: Vijay Iyer Trio
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>One of the leading music makers of his generation, composer/pianist Vijay Iyer returns to Miller with his acclaimed trio featuring the spellbinding bassist Linda May Han Oh and the formidable musician Tyshawn Sorey on drums. Considered &ldquo;the great new jazz piano trio&rdquo;&nbsp;<em>(The New York Times),</em>&nbsp;the ensemble makes emotionally resonant music that is rooted in tradition yet truly innovative.</p>

summary: Embodying Ergonomics: An Imaginative Meditation Experience
locationaddress: Online
description: <p>Imagine your body comfortable and relaxed while working, teaching, or in your clinical practice. By following the principles of ergonomics in a guided meditation, you can not only envision comfort and ease in your workspace, but really begin to feel it as you work.&nbsp; Join this unique meditation experience that encompasses body awareness, relaxation, ergonomics, and more.</p>\n<p><strong>Instructor</strong>: Kevin Myers, MS, AEP, ATC, CLC, the University&rsquo;s Ergonomist,&nbsp;holds a Master of Science in Ergonomics and Biomechanics from New York University, and is a licensed Certified Athletic Trainer and Certified Life Coach.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/DQSMRW3" target="_blank"><strong>REGISTER</strong></a></p>

summary: Organ Meditation

summary: Film Screening & Discussion. "Convenience Store"
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Please join us for the screening of&nbsp;<em>Convenience Store&nbsp;</em>(2022) and Zoom Q&amp;A discussion with the film director&nbsp;<strong>Michael Borodin</strong>. Based on a real story about migrant labor in Moscow, the film casts non-professional actors in a psychedelic drama about modern-day slavery. Mukhabbat works in a typical convenience store on the outskirts of Moscow. Just like other workers in the store she does not get paid for her work and is not allowed to leave. Facing pain, loss and horrible compromises, she makes up her mind to put an end to this life when the owner of the store abducts her newborn son. The film premiered at the 2022 Berlinale festival and received public and critical acclaim drawing attention to the original case and the status of migrant workers from Central Asia in Russia.&nbsp;<em>Convenience Store&nbsp;</em>is the first movie of the Spring 2023 Harriman Film Series&nbsp;<em>Peripheral Vision,&nbsp;</em>which explores the anti-imperial gaze in contemporary Russian cinema.&nbsp;Screening and discussion moderated by&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/mark-lipovetsky/"><strong>Mark Lipovetsky</strong></a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/tatiana-efremova/"><strong>Tatiana Efremova</strong></a>.</p>

summary: Screening: Oscar-nominated documentary Navalny with Director Q&A
locationaddress: Pulitzer Hall, 2950 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The duPont-Columbia Awards presents 2023 duPont Honoree and Oscar-nominated documentary &quot;Navalny.&quot;&nbsp;Offering an extraordinary window into the complicated life and attempted assassination of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, this compelling documentary bears&nbsp;witness as his team works&nbsp;to expose the Russian intelligence agents that shadowed and poisoned him. Cameras continued to roll&nbsp; in the aftermath as Navalny dramatically and historically responded. The screening will be followed by a Q&amp;A with Director Daniel Roher and Professor June Cross of the Columbia Journalism School.</p>\n<p>Registration is required for this event. Register here:&nbsp;https://www.eventbrite.com/e/film-screening-navalny-documentary-a-2023-dupont-awards-honoree-tickets-535177509337</p>

summary: Healthy Eating Basics with a Registered Dietitian
locationaddress: Online
description: <p>Nutrition is something we all know is important, but it can be confusing to figure out what to eat and how to make healthy changes that last. Join us for a discussion on healthy eating with&nbsp;Registered Dietitian, Molly Chanzis, where she will discuss what a nutritious diet looks like, the pros and cons of different eating patterns, and how to implement these recommendations in our everyday lives. You&rsquo;ll leave with a stronger knowledge of nutrition, plus lots of healthy meal and snack ideas.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Presenter: Molly Chanzis, MS, RD, CDN, CDCES is a Registered Dietitian who has been practicing for more than 10 years. Molly is passionate about making nutrition attainable to all, and believes in sustainable lifestyle changes instead of quick fixes. She likes to focus on what foods and habits to add to your life, instead of taking things away. You can find Molly on social media&nbsp;<strong>@sayyestothefresh</strong>&nbsp;where she shares healthy recipes, nutrition tips, and weekly meal plan ideas. She also sees patients through the virtual platform Culina Health.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Join us for the additional events in this&nbsp;semester&#39;s nutrition series!&nbsp; <a href="https://events.columbia.edu/cal/event/eventView.do?b=de&amp;calPath=%2Fpublic%2Fcals%2FMainCal&amp;guid=CAL-00bbdb70-8595c682-0185-97ecc6b6-00003968events@columbia.edu&amp;recurrenceId=" target="_blank">Meal Planning for Busy People</a> (Wednesday, March 8) and a <a href="https://events.columbia.edu/cal/event/eventView.do?b=de&amp;calPath=%2Fpublic%2Fcals%2FMainCal&amp;guid=CAL-00bbdb70-8595c682-0185-97ff9e44-00003b47events@columbia.edu&amp;recurrenceId=" target="_blank">Live Cooking Demo -&nbsp;Quick Prep Meals with a Registered Dietitian</a> (Wednesday, May 3).&nbsp;</p>

summary: Introduction to the Bloomberg Terminal
locationaddress: Online Event
description: <p>Introduction to the navigation and functionally of the Bloomberg Terminal with an emphasis on popular shortcuts. Some of the topics covered are company and industry research, company&rsquo;s financial information like balance sheet, company filings etc. Bloomberg Law, Bloomberg University and Bloomberg Market Concept certificate program.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>

summary: Guided Historical Tour
locationaddress: Low Library, 535 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Tour,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Guided Historical Tour,Visitors Center,org/visitorscenter,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees
description: <p>Join this tour to learn more about the history, architecture, and sculpture of Columbia and the Morningside Heights campus. Whether you&#39;re an amateur New York City historian or visiting campus for the first time, you will leave the tour knowing more about our storied past.</p>\n<p>Tours will depart from the Visitors Center, located in Room 213 in Low Library.&nbsp;Please arrive at least 15 minutes prior to the tour time. Tours take place rain or shine. We encourage guests to dress appropriately based upon the weather conditions of their visit day.</p>\n<p>All Visitors Center visitors are required to bring proof of a primary vaccination series to their campus tour. A list of acceptable documentation can be found <a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/content/faqs-regarding-covid-19-vaccination#!#%2Fcu_accordion_item-4780" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>
